posts.content:
Is your marketing messaging and sales stories aligned and effective?

Effective marketing is a way to tell a story that moves the customer in the right direction.

Your direction. 

It doesnâ€™t matter if you are Bud Light trying to reach a specific audience, or the regional commercial security firm trying to reach health care institutions.

The message is critical and so is the reaching the audience.

Just ask the folks at Bud Light? 

Matt Anderson and I discuss marketing messaging on my podcast Sales and Cigars. You can acess a short clip here.

posts.name:
Subrata (Subu) Biswas
Subrata (Subu) Biswas
posts.content:
Making the transition from a large enterprise to an early-stage startup demands a significant mindset shift. The two have starkly different management and leadership styles. For example, my management style atsignificantly differed from that at. On a day-to-day basis, I make many decisions and bold steps that I would have never taken at Airbnb, as they would have required buy-in from many stakeholders or simply wouldn't make sense there.

While executives in established corporations may view their roles as just another "job," startup founders consider themselves parents of a "fragile newborn in the NICU." Any misstep in strategy or execution could swiftly escalate into a critical situation, which will reflect in the founder's execution strategy.

Hence, working directly with founders in the early stages of a startup can prove challenging, especially for individuals accustomed to the structured environment of a large organization. Startups are not a conventional game. The odds of failure are over 95%. Hence, startup execution strategies are also not conventional. They are purely optimized to increase the survival odds early on and can be highly ambitious and unconventional.

Founders must establish clear expectations from the outset of the hiring process. It is paramount to align the company's mission and career objectives with those of potential hires. Founders should set expectations early on during the hiring process. It's very important to find vision and career objective alignment. It's better to stay away from highly qualified candidates who are just looking for another job!

Similarly, anyone who is planning to join an early-stage startup should understand the clear "Why" of why they want to join a startup.

comments.commentText: Subu you are building something awesome. Rooting for team Cimba.

posts.name:
Cristian Mudure
Cristian Mudure
posts.content:
We recently cracked with Stackfield 20 Mio in revenue. I wish someone told me all this before starting.

1. Ask yourself if your problem is big enough
Ensure the problem you're solving is significant enough to justify building a company around it.

2. Hire generalists
In the early stages, versatile employees who can handle diverse tasks are more valuable than specialists.

3. Don't waste your time on social media. Manage your time wisely
Focus on productive activities instead of getting distracted by social media.

4. Give all employees shares
Sharing equity motivates employees to work towards the companyâ€™s success as if it were their own.

5. Be aware if you scale too fast
Scaling prematurely can lead to organizational and operational chaos.

6. Don't chase big markets from day one. Start in a niche
Begin by dominating a smaller market before expanding into larger ones.

7. Conferences and networking are overrated
Attending endless events may not yield significant results; focus on tangible actions.

8. Don't get nervous if someone copies you
Imitation is inevitable; stay ahead by continually innovating.

9. Be prepared to face a variety of topics: tech, compliance, legal, organization
Running a business means dealing with challenges across multiple disciplines.

10. Managing people is much harder than you think
Building and leading a team is one of the toughest aspects of a business.

11. In customer support, people will insult you
Some customers will vent their frustrations harshly; donâ€™t take it personally.

12. You can't please everyone
Accept that not every decision will satisfy everyone, and thatâ€™s okay.

13. Learn to say no to features
Prioritize features that align with your vision; donâ€™t try to build everything.

14. Technology is only half the battle. Learn to build a business model
Even great tech needs a solid business strategy to succeed.

15. The entire journey is a rollercoaster
Expect emotional highs and lows as part of the entrepreneurial experience.

16. Be ready to make sacrifices. Founding means giving things up
Entrepreneurship often requires sacrificing personal time and comfort. If you prefer a 9-to-5 job, thatâ€™s fine, but it wonâ€™t take you far.

17. Ideally, start in your native language for better support
Begin with a smaller, localized audience to provide superior customer support before scaling globally.

18. Bootstrap only if you can endure hardship
Without external funding, prepare for financial and emotional challenges.

19. Brand and trust are everything
Building a strong brand and trust with your customers is crucial for long-term success.

20. Donâ€™t get complacent when things are going well
Success can lead to overconfidence and stagnation. Stay vigilant, keep innovating, and always look for ways to improve and adapt, even when the business is thriving.

comments.commentText:
Cristian Mudure Congratulations on reaching 20 Mio in revenue! Your insights are spot on, especially the importance of building a strong brand and trust with customers. I would also add that having a clear and compelling mission statement can help guide decision-making and inspire employees. Additionally, it's important to prioritize continuous learning and personal growth as a founder, as the business will only thrive if its leaders are constantly improving. Finally, don't underestimate the power of a supportive network of mentors, advisors, and peers in navigating the ups and downs of entrepreneurship.
â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”

Andrei Bogdan ï¸ Thank you! Well, maybe that everything always takes much longer than expected. I started Stackfield back in 2012, itâ€™s been a really long time, and it only really started taking off after 7 or 8 years.

Navigating workplace relationships can be challenging. You might click with your coworkers, but letâ€™s face itâ€”not every colleague is a close friend. And thatâ€™s completely normal!

Work connections are usually about shared goals and responsibilities, not personal bonds.

While collaboration and respect are crucial, expecting deeper friendships at work can blur boundaries and lead to misunderstandings.

posts.content:
I rejected the CEO of a $423M company.

And it made me $400k. Hereâ€™s how:

In 2018, I hit rock bottom.

No job. No degree. No plan.

â†’ I applied for hundreds of roles
â†’ Only 2 gave me a shot and
â†’ One was a $423M giant.

The CEO sat across from me.

And said:

â†’ â€œYouâ€™re too good for this roleâ€
â†’ â€œYouâ€™ll get boredâ€
â†’ â€œYou wonâ€™t thriveâ€

They offered me the job.

I said no to.

Why?

Because I believed in Company B.

(before Covid)

I happily accepted their offer 

Thenâ€¦

Zoom rejected me.

â†’ No job.
â†’ No income.
â†’ No clue what to do next.

But hereâ€™s where it changes.

â†’ A childhood friend worked there
â†’ We werenâ€™t even close.
â†’ But Iâ€™d always been kind to him.

And he remembered.

â†’ He fought for me for months
â†’ He chased it to Zoom's CMO
â†’ He went out on a limb for me.

And weeks later, out of the blue

Zoom called me back.
They gave me the job.

â†’ That role changed my life.
â†’ Promoted 3 times in 3 years
â†’ Making $400k in commissions.

The lesson?

â†’ Trust builds over time and
â†’ Treating everyone with kindness
â†’ Compounds faster than Bitcoin.

And you never know what it will pay you.

Agree?
